text: this ball of cells is the embryo of a
tiny organism called Volvox it's about
to turn itself inside out it's called
inversion and scientists at Cambridge
University used an advanced kind of
light microscopy so that for the first
time we can see what happens in three
dimensions they did it to confirm their
mathematical model of the process
imagine a basketball with a hole in the
top you want to turn it inside out so
you shrink the bottom to push it through
that hole that's what Volvox does the
sales change shape but they don't change
their position in relation to other
cells inversion is interesting to
scientists because something very
similar happens to the embryos of humans
and all sorts of animals after all it's
a pretty important distinction for any
living thing what's inside what's
outside
